info.mission_statement.md:
We, the "Dat Ecosystem" members, come together to achieve the following goals:

  • Share our knowledge on building decentralized systems.
  • Publish our work under permissive, open culture, licenses.
  • Build decentralized systems that profit the general public and empower users.
  • Have dat protocols (e.g. hypercore-protocol or similar) as a foundation of our work.
  • Promote our shared goals with the public.
  • Develop solutions to shared technical problems.
  • Find and invite new members that share our goals.
  • Promote the adoption of shared technology through documentation or standardization.

This group is governed by individuals that form together "the Consortium". The Consortium works to:

  • Enact our code of conduct.
  • Raise and maintain funds and assets to fulfill the goals.
  • Use decentralized systems wherever feasible.
  • Publicly and transparently document the process and offer the public a means to comment.
  • Coordinate efforts by members.
  • Communicate on discord/cabal

Proposals are submitted as pull requests to /consortium/decisions/{YYY}.{MM}.{DD}-{proposal_name}.md in organization repository.
Proposals to change the manifesto are submitted as pull requests to change the manifesto itself.
Proposer needs to tag all consortium members in the pull request and notify consortium members in the active consortium communication channel.

Decisions will be done through voting by consortium members. The voting period lasts 2 weeks.
Regular voting items are accepted unless there is opposition by at least one Consortium member. Members may state opposition beforehands.

The addition of a member or changes to this Manifesto requires unanimous support by all Consortium members.
The removal of one member requires unanimous support by all Consortium members except by the member in question.
After a consortium member is tagged in a proposals pull request and the consortium communication channel and that member does not respond within 3 months, their consortium membership becomes dormant, which means they do not count as consortium member in the context of deciding about any proposals.
Dormant consortium members can reactivate themselves at any given time to become normal consortium members again unilateraly.
Consortium Members can end their consortium membership and remove themselves from the consortium membership list at any given time unilateraly.

Consortium members (alphabetic order):

  • Alexander Cobleigh
  • Alexander Praetorius
  • Diego Paez
  • Franz Heinzmann
  • Kevin Faaborg
  • Nina Breznik

home.about_us: Dat projects in its core build tools and infrastructure for distributed data syncronization. But as people and technologists we stand for Sustainable Open Source, Modularity & Technical Inclusion, Local First & Cloudless, Social Impact & Cooperative Ownership, Non-extractive Business Models, Data Sovereignty & Access Control. Dat's first project was a protocol which later grew to become the independent project (hypercore protocol). Today Dat ecosystem is a global community of many projects working side by side on open and secure protocols for the web of commons.
home.cover: Dat ecosystem is driven forward by many projects, most self funded. Some of the projects contribute maintainance and development to core pieces of the Dat ecosystem while others create high level applications built on top of p2p protocols.

timeline.title: dat - brainstorming an idea
timeline.desc: Max Ogden chats with Rufus Pollock about a changes protocol for data to allow diffing/merging and supports micro-schemas at the Open Government Data Camp

timeline.title: Knight Foundation Funding ($50.000)
timeline.desc: Brings dat (as http://dat-data.com) from an idea to the pre-alpha stage

timeline.title: dat - initial readme
timeline.desc: Dat is created by Max Ogden in 2013 to standardize the way data analysts collaborate on the changes they make to data sets. Rufus Pollock from the Open Knowledge Foundation describes it as git (and github) for data

timeline.title: twitter account
timeline.desc: @dat_protocol twitter account is created (later renamed to @dat_ecosystem)

timeline.title: introducing dat
timeline.desc: Max Ogden presents Dat at the Strata Conference in London

timeline.title: Alfred P. Sloan Foundation Funding ($260.000)
timeline.desc: Helps dat to become an US ODI (Open Data Institute) project

timeline.title: peermaps
timeline.desc: Peermaps is born (peer to peer cartography)

timeline.title: dat - beta
timeline.desc: Dat Beta version is released -  the version focused on tabular datasets. It turns out to be too complex for typical use cases

timeline.title: designing dat 1.0
timeline.desc: Designing dat 1.0, rOpenSci Community Call v8

timeline.title: alpha testing
timeline.desc: Alpha testing with pilot projects in science, including Sloan Digital Sky Survey (Astronomy), iRNA-Seq (Bioinformatics – RNA), and Bionode (Bioinformatics – DNA)Hypercore v1.0.0 is released

timeline.title: Knight Foundation Funding ($420.000)
timeline.desc: Knight Foundation Grant ($420.000) for Publicbeats project

timeline.title: Code for Science and Society
timeline.desc: Code for Science and Society is founded - to support the Dat Project as a fiscal sponsor bundled with strategic project support

timeline.title: first meetups
timeline.desc: The first meetups for ‘Coding for Science & Society’ are held in Berlin, Oakland, and Portland; organized by the Dat team

timeline.title: Moore Foundation Grant ($110.000)
timeline.desc: Moore Foundation grant for collaboration of dat and California Digital Library (CDL)

timeline.title: organizational changes
timeline.desc: Organizational Changes for Dat and Code for Science & Society

timeline.title: Beaker browser and the Dat protocol analysis
timeline.desc: Beaker browser and the Dat protocol: An analysis for COMP 117: Internet-scale Distributed Systems is released

timeline.title: kappa core
timeline.desc: Kappa Core 1.0 is released (minimal append only DB)

timeline.title: Mozila Open Source Support Grant ($34,000)
timeline.desc: Dat Project Receives Mozilla Open Source Support Grant

timeline.title: dat open collective
timeline.desc: Dat Open Collective page is set up for recurring donations

timeline.title: how dat works
timeline.desc: How dat works visualization project is started

timeline.title: Samsung NEXT Stack Zero Grant ($63.000)
timeline.desc: Samsung NEXT Stack Zero grant is received

timeline.title: Wireline Donation ($50,000)
timeline.desc: Dat Project receives donation from Wireline

timeline.title: mapeo by digital democracy
timeline.desc: Mapeo by Digital Democracy joins the ecosystem

timeline.title: Hypercore protocol graduates from Dat Ecosystem
timeline.desc: Dat protocol is renamed to Hypercore protocol

timeline.title: NLnet grant ($50.000)
timeline.desc: NLnet grant is recieved for a Rust port

timeline.title: dat manifesto
timeline.desc: Dat consortium forms Dat Ecosystem and consoritum members sign a manifesto

timeline.title: Code for Science and Society grant ($20.000)
dat ecosystem archive
timeline.desc: Dat ecosystem archive is created to archive all the historic repositories

timeline.title: geut - sher
timeline.desc: Geut studio introduces new project Sher

timeline.title: dcent reads
timeline.desc: Dcent Reads, a platform for decentralised publishing joins the ecosystem

timeline.title: wizard amigos code camp
timeline.desc: wizard amigos code camp is organized in Wales

timeline.title: HOP
timeline.desc: HOP (health oracle protocol) joins the ecosystem

timeline.title: dat ecosystem visualized
timeline.desc: webscape wanderer visualizer engine is created to visualize dat ecosystem

timeline.title: hyper-nostr
timeline.desc: hypercore-nostr relay is published and project joins the ecosystem

timeline.title: demo & AMA sessions
timeline.desc: demo sessions and AMA commm comm calls launch

timeline.title: wizard amigos code camp
timeline.desc: wizard amigos code camp is organized in Portugal

timeline.title: new dat ecosystem web page is released
timeline.desc: Dat ecosystem releases new web page

timeline.title: DatRS has a restart
timeline.desc: After work on rust implementations has been dormant for a while, it has found a new project lead who puts the focus on Hypercore and Hyperbee core modules

timeline.title: Keet - new important release
timeline.desc: We've got a new version (v2.5.0) out which improves the look and feel along with fixes for the #Hypercore / #Holepunch protocol handlers.

timeline.title: Agregore -new version (v2.5.0)
timeline.desc: We've got a new version (v2.5.0) out which improves the look and feel along with fixes for the #Hypercore / #Holepunch protocol handlers.

timeline.title: Dat Ecosystem Joins Apereo Foundation
timeline.desc: Dat Ecosystem joined the Apereo Foundation as a fiscally sponsored project

timeline.title: Bare - new javascript runtime
timeline.desc: Small and modular JavaScript runtime for desktop and mobile. Like Node.js, it provides an asynchronous, event-driven architecture for writing applications in the lingua franca of modern software. Unlike Node.js, it makes embedding and cross-device support core use cases, aiming to run just as well on your phone as on your laptop. The result is a runtime ideal for networked, peer-to-peer applications that can run on a wide selection of hardware.

timeline.title: webscape wanderer - new release
timeline.desc: New refined and cleaned up release is out

timeline.title: v0.3.0 BETA of BentoBoxDS
timeline.desc: v0.3.0 BETA of BentoBoxDS is available for desktop

timeline.title: WizardAmigos demo
timeline.desc: WizardAmigos student has finished his internship project and built a p2p news app in the browser. All based on bare runtime and hypercore and hyperswarm.

timeline.title: Keet - new release (v4.5.0)
timeline.desc: New desktop and mobile features released

projects.project_desc: Agregore, a browser for the distributed web, facilitates peer-to-peer data sharing without central servers, supporting protocols like BitTorrent and IPFS for direct loading and sharing of content.

Āhau is a Whānau Data Platform that helps whānau-based communities (whānau, hapū, Iwi) capture, preserve, and share important information and histories into secure, whānau managed databases and servers.

Ara represents a new era for content on the internet. Where we get our voices back. Where what's ours is ours. All content, decentralized, secure, owned, distributed, paid for, and rewarded between peers.

Cabal is an experimental P2P community chat platform where servers are unnecessary, everything runs locally, and each community is identified by a secret key, offering both internet and local network connectivity.
DataShell - A Peer-to-Peer Prototyping Environment for Web Apps with User-Owned Data Vaults
Rust implementation of the core dat protocol (hypercore)
DatDot enables peer-to-peer sharing of storage space and data seeding to make data sovereignity and portability more accessible and reliable for users.
Dcent Beats is an anti-platform seeking to connect musicians directly with their audience without taking a percentage just for being in the way.
DXOS provides developers with everything they need to build real-time, collaborative apps which run entirely on the client, and communicate peer-to-peer, without servers.
An experimental mobile browser that aims to help build a sustainable community-owned P2P web.
We are building a choherence protocol based on peer to peer open source software and toolkit that empower everyone to have sovereignity over data that shapes the health of the world.
The goal of this tool is to behave as a public relay; think of the chosen topic as a public relay, where you can send and receive notes from your peers!
Hypercore is a secure, distributed append-only log built for sharing large datasets and streams of real-time data.
Keet only shares end-to-end encrypted data between the participants in every call. Without middlemen, third-parties, or servers, there’s nobody left who can snoop on calls, leak or collect data.
Empowering developers to build the future of P2P apps with zero infrastructure cost. Revolutionize how we connect, share, and create with Pear Runtime.
Mapeo is a free digital toolset for documenting, monitoring, and mapping many types of data.

Peermaps is a distributed, offline-friendly alternative to commercial map providers such as google maps. Instead of fetching data from a centralized tile service, your computer fetches map data from other peers across the network.
PeerShare enables you to share files to your friends, family, colleagues etc, using peer-to-peer technology. With a clean, easy to read interface, you can share your files right away.
PeerViewer is a remote desktop and support solution, completely free for unlimited personal and commercial use.
0% Backend, 10'000% Frontend
It's simple. You create your show and share the link with your audience.
Build mobile and destkop apps for any OS using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Connect users with modern P2P that can make the cloud entirely optional.
Sonar is based on the Hypercore Protocol and part of the Dat ecosystem of peer-to-peer tools.
An interactive visualization engine for open source ecosystems

Wizard Amigos is a global community of self-employed nomadic developers, technologists, creators, problem solvers, thinkers, activists, researchers, artists, and individuals from diverse backgrounds who share a common passion for technology and open collaboration.
